JDBCTM RowSet Implementations Specification
JSR 114 Final Draft

JDBCTM RowSet Implementations Specification (JSR 114)

See:
          Description

Packages
javax.sql.rowset Standard interfaces and base classes for JDBC RowSet implementations.
javax.sql.rowset.serial Provides utility classes to allow serializable mappings between SQL types and data types in the Java programming language.
javax.sql.rowset.spi The standard classes and interfaces that a third party vendor has to use in its implementation of a synchronization provider.

 

JDBCTM RowSet Implementations Specification (JSR 114)

This is the Maintenance Release 1.0.1 of JSR 114 API.

Please send all comments to jsr-114-comments@jcp.org. We appreciate all feedback!

1.0 Introduction

This document describes the JDBCTM RowSet Implementations Specification (JSR-114). The purpose is to define a standard for implementations of the JDBC RowSet model, in addition to defining a service provider framework for disconnected synchronizations.

The final version of this specification will be incorporated into the Java 2 Platform, Standard Edition Version 1.5 (J2SDK 1.5). Furthermore, the Reference Implementation, which represents the standard operational definition of this specification will be bundled with the J2SDK 1.5 platform. A Technology Compatibility Kit (TCK) will also be made available to permit and encourage other implementations of this specification to become compliant. This follows the rules laid out in the Java Community Process 2.1.

The JSR 114 API is targeted at two distinct audiences:

  • Driver vendors that implement the JDBC API and intend to provide standard JDBC RowSet implementations.
  • ASP's that provide middle-tier services above the JDBC driver layer

The specification is also intended to serve the following purposes:

  • An introduction for end-users whose applications use the JDBC RowSet implementations
  • A starting point for developers of other APIs layered on top of the JDBC API

3.0 Goals

The JDBC 3.0 API specification provides a set of standard interfaces that define the functionality of all JDBC RowSet objects. To standardize implementations of these interfaces, this specification aims to define a set of JDBC RowSet Implementations using a common set of APIs and utility classes.

In addition, we to standardize the means by which disconnected JDBC RowSet objects communicate with underlying data stores by defining standard set of syncrhonization semantics.

  • Fit into J2SE and J2EE Platforms The JDBC RowSet Implementations are a constituent part of the Java platform. Therefore, they must align with the architechtural direction and needs of the Java 2 Standard Edition and Java 2 Enterprise Edition platforms.
  • Remain consistent with JDBC 3.0 API. All standard RowSet implementations need to be consisent with the JDBC 3.0 API.
  • Ensure suitability for the Web Tier.Web tier technologies such as JavaServer Faces and JavaServer Pages Standard Tag Library (JSTL) require a standard way to access relational and non-relational tabular data. All design considerations should reflect the needs of the Web tier developer.
  • Keep it simple! A key benefit of the JDBC RowSet Implementations design is that it maintains a simple model enscapsulating the table/row/column concept that is well understood by a wide cross section of developers.

4.0 Non Goals

  • Support for extensive SQL functionality. While the API should provide standard means to manipulate RowSet data, it is beyond the scope of this specification to provide full portable and serializable SQL processing functionality to each RowSet component.
  • Support for a higher-level API. It is expected that programmers will want to use this API at a more abstract level, however the provisions of such APIs is beyond the scope of this specification. Efforts have been made to ensure more abstract APIs such as Java Data Objects (JDO) can easily leverage this specification.

5.0 Requirements & Compliance

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

Furthermore, JDBC drivers used by a JDBC RowSet Implementation must comply with the JDBC 3.0 API compliance requirements. These are listed below:

5.1 JDBC 3.0 Specification Requirements

  • A JDBC API implementation must support Entry Level SQL92 plus the SQL command Drop Table
  • Entry Level SQL92 represents a "floor" for the level of SQL that a JDBC API implementation must support. Access to features based on SQL99 should be provided in a way that is compatible with the relevant part of the SQL99 specification.
  • Drivers must support escape syntax.
  • Drivers must support transactions.
  • Drivers should provide access to every feature implemented by the underlying data source, including features that extend the JDBC API. When a feature is not supported, the corresponding methods throw an SQLException. The intent is for applications using the JDBC API to have access to the same feature set as native applications.
  • If a DatabaseMetaData method indicates that a given feature is supported, it must be supported via standard syntax and semantics as described in the relevant specifications. This may require the driver to provide the mapping to the data source's native API or SQL dialect if it differs from the standard.
  • If a feature is supported, all of the relevant metadata methods must be implemented. For example, if a JDBC API implementation supports the RowSet interface, it must also implement the RowSetMetaData interface.
  • If a feature is not supported, the corresponding DatabaseMetaData method must say so. Attempting to access the unsupported feature causes an SQLException to be thrown.
5.2 JDBC RowSet Specification Requirements

  • A JDBC RowSet implementation must support at a minimum the interfaces JdbcRowSet and its parent interfaces defined in the javax.sql package. This represents the base level of JDBC RowSet support.
  • Thereafter, a JDBC RowSet implementation may choose to implement specific interfaces in the javax.sql.rowset package.
  • A JDBC RowSet implementation that operates in a disconnected environment must use the SyncFactory SPIs to manage SyncProvider objects, which provide reader/writer capabilities.
  • A JDBC RowSet implementation must implement of one or more standard RowSet definition and may extend the BaseRowSet class. This ensures standard API signature's and consistent JavaBeans event handling.

As a constituent part of the Java platform, compliance with the JDBC RowSet Implementations is determined as a subset of evaluating compliance of the overall Java platform.

NOTE: As of this writing, there is no specific evaluation of the compliance level for the JDBC RowSet Implementations.

6.0 Definitions

  • JDBC RowSet Implementations. Implementations of the interfaces described in the javax.sql.rowset package.
  • Service Provider Factory. A factory mechanism that generates instances of service providers. In case of JSR-114, the service provider factory SyncFactory generates SyncProvider classes described below.
  • Service Provider. A SyncProvider using a JDBC driver or other means of connecting to a data source and the underlying data source. The JDBC driver may provide support for features not implemented by the underlying data source in addition to not being exclusively a JDBC driver. The SyncProvider mechanism provides synchronization between disconnected RowSets and any tabular data source, including XML based data sources.
  • Relevant Specifications. This document, JDBC 3.0 API specification, and the relevant SQL specifications when dealing with relational data sources. See the JDBC 3.0 specification for details on the variations in pure JDBC support. The W3C specifications relevant to XML Schema processing are the basis for the XML support.
  • Supported Feature. A feature that is implemented using standard syntax and semantics as defined in this specification.
  • Extension. A feature that is covered by any of the relevant specifications or a non-standard implementation of a features that is covered.
  • Fully implemented. A term applied to an interface that has all of its methods implemented to support the semantics defined in the relevant specifications.
  • Required interface. An interface that must be included although it might not be fully implemented. Methods that are not implemented should throw an SQLException to indicate that the corresponding feature is not implemented.

7.0 API Dependencies

  • J2SE (JDK) 1.4 or higher
  • JDBC 3.0 API Specification

8.0 Package Overview

The JSR 114 API consists of 3 standard packages:
  • javax.sql.rowset
  • javax.sql.rowset.spi
  • javax.sql.rowset.serial

The javax.sql.rowset package contains the RowSet interfaces that describe the models used to manipulate tabular data in the disconnected and connected environments. Noteworthy interfaces include the JdbcRowSet and CachedRowSet that describe RowSets that work in the connected and disconnected environment respectively. Additionally, helper classes such as the BaseRowSet provide standard event handling mechanisms for all RowSet implementations.

The javax.sql.rowset.spi package contains the factory classes and abstract class definitions that describe the Service Provider Interface infrastructure for JSR-114. The classes and factory mechanisms provide a choice of multiple pluggable synchronization providers to disconnected RowSet implementations such as the CachedRowSet. Standard exception definitions and mechanisms are also described to provide a standard way to resolve synchronization conflicts.

The javax.sql.rowset.serial package provides a set of utility classes that assist in the serialization of complex SQL data types contained with a standard RowSet tabular data structure. Of note here is the SerialStruct class that provides a standard mechanism to serialize SQL STRUCT data types.

The reference implementation of JSR-114 is provided in the com.sun.rowset and com.sun.rowset.providers packages. These are described in the reference implementation Javadoc and are available seperately. Please check the JDBC technology homepage for further details.

9.0 Service Providers

The Service Provider Interface (SPI) defined in JSR-114 defines a means by which synchronization providers or implementations of the SyncProvider abstract class can be dynamically plugged into the SPI and then generated by the SPI factory mechanism when requested by a disconnected RowSet.

The reference implementation of JSR-114 provides two implementations of the SyncProvider abstract class that are pluggable with the SPI and must always be available to all disconnected RowSet objects. Full and concrete implementations of the SyncProvider must provide implementations of the javax.sql.RowSetReader, javax.sql.RowSetWriter and the javax.sql.RowSetInternal interfaces. In addition, all methods described in SyncProvider must be implemented to ensure the provider is pluggable into the SPI.

For example, the reference implementation provides two such SyncProvider implementations in the com.sun.rowset.providers package. This package is described in the reference implementation documentation. The RIOptimitiscProvider provides synchronization with SQL data sources (using a JDBC driver) and the RIXMLProvider provides syncrhonization with XML data sources (using JAX-P). The SPI factory mechanism, SyncFactory has the ability to generate the refernce implementation providers if requested by a RowSet. Additional provider implementations may also be registered with the factory, requested by a RowSet and subsequently generated by the factory. The pluggable allows disconnected RowSet objects to obtain a widerange of synchronization semantics to suit their needs.

10.0 Open Issues

    Final Draft Issues None.

11.0 Closed Issues

    White Paper Topics

  • SMI-36: ADO.Net Alignment and .Net interoperability
  • SMI-37: Add a Sort capability to the FilteredRowSet interface definition

    Proposed Final Draft Issues

  • SMI-30: Positional methods in RowSets are not specific as thread safe
  • SMI-31: Joinable interface. Remove match methods from JdbcRowSet
  • SMI-32: JoinRowSet - Possible missing functionality
  • SMI-33, DD-PFD-1: SQL/XML and WebRowSet ? a closer alignment
  • SMI-34: SyncProviderException should describe synchronization conflicts in greater detail
  • SMI-35: Additional event notification for JDNC
  • SMI-38: RowSet migration policies and mechanics
  • SMI-39: Re-organization of specification
  • SMI-40, DD-PFD-2: Auto-commit should not be the default commit mode
  • SMI-41: Relationship to Stored Procedures
  • SMI-42: Add a DataSet like capability to the JDBC RowSet class hierarchy
  • SMI-43: Expose each CachedRowSet row as a JavaBean / (Related to: SMI-35)

    Public Review Issues

  • DD-CRD-18: Further clarification with regard to release and close method calls. Need to obtain expert group sign off on specification of these methods.
  • DD-PR-1: Clarify usage and overlap between cancelDelete, cancelInsert, cancelUpdate
  • DD-PR-2: toCollection method - TreeMap Collection
  • DD-PR-3: addRowSet in JoinRowSet needs clarification
  • SMI-1, DD-PR-4: SQL/XML / WebRowSet schema alignment
  • SMI-2: RowSet MetaData - how to provide RowSet metadata while over-riding metadata from ResultSet
  • SMI-3: RowSet .updateURL for DATALINK types
  • SMI-4: Align with EJB 2.1 specification
  • SMI-5: Need to clarify the update through view issue. What updates are permitted for JoinRowSets, FilteredRowSets and CachedRowSets. How early are exceptions detected.
  • SMI-6: Is it to insert a row into aa FilteredRowSet if the insert row violates the filter criteria ?
  • SMI-7: CachedRowSet: what if an update violates original query ?
  • SMI-8: Need to specify expcetions, behavior or guidelines through which portable apps can be achieved.
  • SMI-9: What is the relationship of restting JOIN property for a JoinRowSet and action on a view into a database. If a JoinRowSet is not a CachedRowSet. Is this static or dynamic ?
  • SMI-10: What is the relationship between cloned, copied and shared data. Who sees the updates when ? What do I see if I do a restoreOriginal on the original rowset ?
  • SMI-11: acceptChanges: first problem row may be a read row, not an updated row. Should this be reflected depending on grade?
  • SMI-12: createCopy -- same backing store if acceptChanges is called
  • SMI-13: setMatchColumn: Seemed lke this method belongs on JRS instead
  • SMI-14: Some of RowSet methods are internal only: seperate out to other interface ?
  • SMI-15: setConcurrency - who calls this method ?
  • SMI-16: Grades - locking and OCC grades are not mutually exclusive (i.e not orthogonal or ordered). What does grade none mean ?
  • SMI-17: SyncProvider - need to be able to set grades. To be able to set logical isolation on per CachedRowSet basis. This may be very useful for higher level frameworks and tools.
  • SMI-18: DataSourceLock - what is this ? Does it apply to multiple tables or schema ?
  • SMI-19: setDataSoruceLock -- when can this be called ? How long are these locks held ?
  • SMI-20: What can be done with regard to SyncProviders options etc ? Need to specify interactions of thsi API with CachedRowSet user actions. eg., can only set locking or grade level before a CRS is materialized etc.
  • SMI-21: JdbcRowSet needs to provide a clear definition of its role in the connected environment only.
  • SMI-22: (URL methods in BaseRowSet require further clarification
  • SMI-24: JoinRowSet.toRowSet() needs further clarification
  • SMI-25: CachedRowSet.getWarnings needs further clarification
  • SMI-26: Alignment with JAX-B
  • SMI-27: Alignment with JAX-RPC
  • SMI-28: Editorial issues from Docs
  • SMI-29: Work estimate from TCK engineers
  • ORCL-1: Enabling non-generic schema support
  • ORCL-2: JoinRowSet is unclear as to whether is can support more that two RowSets at a time
